answers: fundamental theorem of algebra [prompt on partial answer]
parts: Carl Friedrich Gauss formulated this theorem, stating that for a polynomial with complex coefficients and degree greater than one, there is at least one complex root.
This other German mathematician’s namesake Basis Theorem concerns rings of polynomials being Noetherian. This man also composed a list of 23 unsolved problems.

This French mathematician is the namesake of polynomials that are orthogonal over the interval [-1,1] with a weighing function of 1.. His namesake transform converts between the Lagrangian and the Hamiltonian.
Name this country, whose second-most populous city is Aarhus. This country contains the world’s oldest amusement park, Bakken.
Bakken, the world’s oldest amusement park, lies near this capital of Denmark. It also famously contains Tivoli Gardens and a bronze statue of the Little Mermaid.
Copenhagen is on this largest island of Denmark. This island separated from its western neighbor by the Little Belt.
A prince of this dynasty, Maslama ibn Abd al-Malik, besieged Constantinople in 717.. This dynasty’s failure to capture Constantinople was a major factor behind its eventual overthrow by the Abbasids.

This dynasty, founded by Ismail I, often fought against the Ottomans and was modernized with the help of the Shirley brothers. This dynasty is responsible for the presence of Shia Islam in Iran today.
This Berber dynasty centered in Morocco decisively defeated an alliance of Iberian kings at the Battle of Sagrajas. This dynasty was overthrown in 1147 by the Almohads.
This author wrote “to err is human, to forget divine” in An Essay on Criticism.
Alexander Pope also wrote The Rape of the Lock, in which Ariel is unable to prevent the Baron from cutting this object belonging to Belinda.
The Rape of the Lock and The Dunciad are examples of this satirical genre that Pope famously wrote. Works in this genre often parody common archetypes of brave figures.
The name of this Swedish pop supergroup is an acronym for the first names of its two couples. This group broke records with the 1976 worldwide hit Dancing Queen.

This Swedish DJ behind Waiting for Love and The Nights rose to prominence after his 2013 song Wake Me Up. Having suffered from mental health problems for years, he took his own life in Muscat, Oman in 2018.
This Swedish singer collaborated with Clean Bandit on Symphony. Her own hits include Never Forget You and Lush Life.

answers: Netherlands [accept Holland; prompt on the Dutch Republic]
parts: Baruch Espinoza was a leading thinker of this country’s Golden Age. Espinoza studied at the prestigious University of Leiden in this country, and he was born in this country’s capital of Amsterdam.
This Dutch jurist was known for his theories regarding war justified by natural law principles. He dedicated his seminal On the Law of War and Peace to his patron, King Louis XIII of France.
This other prominent Dutch thinker advocated a “middle road” approach to reforming the Catholic Church. This friend of Sir Thomas More wrote Handbook of a Christian Knight and In Praise of Folly.
Name this technique in which mixtures are separated by spinning the mixture at very high speeds.
Centrifugation is commonly used to separate this substance from the blood. This yellowish liquid makes up about 55% of the volume of human blood, and unlike serum it contains fibrinogen.
Sedimentation coefficients in centrifugation are commonly measured in this man’s namesake non-SI units. This Swedish chemist invented the first analytical ultracentrifuge.
Name this collection by Giovanni Boccaccio consisting of 100 tales.
In a story from The Decameron, this Marquis of Saluzzo tests his wife Griselda by telling her he killed their two children. In reality, this character sent them to Bologna.
The seven women and three men in The Decameron flee from this city due to the Black Death. Either this city or Certaldo was the birthplace of Giovani Boccacio.
Name these pieces from the collection The Contest Between Harmony and Invention. Trills imitate bird calls in the first of this set of pieces.
The Four Seasons is a set of violin concertos by this Italian Baroque composer nicknamed “The Red Priest”.

Leonid Desyatnikov arranged this composer’s The Four Seasons of Buenos Aires for solo violin and string orchestra, making it more similar to Vivaldi’s work. By blending traditional Argentine tango with jazz and classical music, this composer created the “nuevo tango” style.

answers: Confederate States of America [accept CSA or Confederacy]
parts: It was given by this “Little Pale Star from Georgia” who addressed a “new government” founded on the principle that “the negro is not equal to the white man.”
Alexander Stephens was the first and only vice president of this former country, who fought a civil war against the Union. This country’s president was Jefferson Davis.
The Cornerstone Speech was given a month before this battle, where Confederate general P. G. T. Beauregard fired on Robert Anderson’s garrison.
Name this god who hung himself from Yggdrasil for nine nights to gain knowledge of the different runes. This god is the All-Father and the chief god in Norse mythology.
To drink from this figure’s well, Odin sacrifices an eye. Odin carries this figure’s severed head for counsel and advice.
Odin transforms into a snake to slither into a mountain to drink the mead of poetry, a mixture of this god’s blood and honey. This god was born from the collected spit of the Aesir and the Vanir.
Name this molecule, which unlike RNA uses thymine alongside adenine, cytosine and guanine. This molecule encodes an organism’s genetics.
DNA winds around these proteins to form chromatin. Nucleosomes contain 8 of these proteins.
Histones contain large amounts of lysine and this amino acid. This positively charged molecule is the most hydrophilic amino acid and it's one letter symbol is R.
Name this jazz standard composed by Paul Desmond. A repetitive E flat minor two chord vamp persists throughout this song.
This musician’s namesake quartet released hits such as “Take Five” and “Blue Rondo a la Turk” in the album Time Out.
Brubeck was a player of this instrument, also played by Thelonius Monk and Duke Ellington. A pentatonic scale can be played using only this instrument’s black keys.
Name this novel that ends with the unveiling of a statue of the title explorer, who previously fell in love with Laura Trevelyan.
This author of Voss also wrote of the painter Hurtle Duffield in The Vivisector.
Patrick White was an author from this country. Oscar and Lucinda transport a glass cathedral to Bellingen in New South Wales in a Peter Carey novel set in this country.

answers: Patrick Anthony McCarran [accept McCarran International Airport]
parts: During a speech in Wheeling, this Wisconsin senator accused 205 members of the state department of being Communists. This senator’s namesake “ism” grew to prominence during the Second Red Scare.
This senator was an avid admirer of Francisco Franco and a strong opponent of communist expansion. In 2017, a movement surfaced to rename his namesake airport in Las Vegas after Harry Reid.
This South Carolina Senator infamously filibustered the 1957 Civil Rights Act for over twenty four hours. He ran with Fielding Wright on the Dixiecrat ticket in the 1948 Presidential Election.

answers: nuclear fission [do not accept or prompt on “nuclear fusion”]
Irène Joliot-Curie [accept Irène Curie; prompt on Curie]
parts: Name this Austrian-Swiss physicist who is the namesake of element 109.. With her nephew Otto Frisch, she solved the theoretical puzzle of how barium could be formed from uranium.
Meitner was controversially not awarded a Nobel prize for her role in the discovery of this phenomenon. Nuclei undergoing this energetic process split into two or more smaller nuclei.

The discovery of fission built directly on the work of this other physicist and her husband Frederic. She and her husband were jointly awarded a Nobel Prize in 1935 for their discovery of artificial radioactivity through bombarding aluminum with alpha particles.
Name this artist, who also depicted a couple in an amorous embrace in The Waltz.
While in Paris, Claudel became an apprentice to, and later the lover of, this artist. This sculptor of The Thinker depicted six men with nooses around their necks in The Burghers of Calais.
As an apprentice, Claudel helped sculpt many of the hands and feet in this work by Rodin. Paolo and Francesca are depicted in The Kiss, which was originally part of this larger work.

answers: I Know Why the Caged Bird Sings
parts: Name this novel, which details the protagonist and her brother Bailey’s upbringing by their grandmother in Stamps, Arkansas.
This author of Still I Rise wrote the semi-autobiographical novel I Know Why the Caged Bird Sings. She read her poem On the Pulse of Morning at Bill Clinton’s inauguration.
The title of I Know Why the Caged Bird Sings references this author’s poem “Sympathy.” He wrote about the title object, which “grins and lies” in “We Wear the Mask.”

answers: Battle of Adwa (or Battle of Adowa)

Austria-Hungary [or The Kingdoms and Lands Represented in the Imperial Council and the Lands of the Holy Hungarian Crown of St. Stephen; do not accept or prompt on “Austria” or “Hungary” or “Austrian Empire”]
parts: During World War Two, the Kingdom of Italy invaded this nation which at the time was led by Ioannis Metaxas from Athens.
The Kingdom of Italy's invasion of Ethiopia was stopped at this humiliating battle. The Ethiopians, who were led by Menelik II, acquired guns from Russia which helped them achieve victory.

The Kingdom of Italy fought against this nation and its ally Germany at the Battle of Caporetto which was a decisive victory for this nation. This nation used the acronym k.u.k to represent its dual monarchy.

In a November 2020 press conference, an unidentified dark liquid dripped down the side of this man’s face as he alleged widespread election fraud in a parking lot. This former mayor previously served as President Trump’s personal lawyer.
Giuliani’s “star witness” in Michigan was this oft-ridiculed Dominion contractor, who claimed without evidence that illegal ballots were smuggled into Detroit’s TCF center using meal vans.

Sydney Powell, another pro-Trump lawyer, pushed unsubstantiated claims that Dominion voting machines were compromised by this South American country. An unsuccessful invasion of this country in Operation Gideon led to the arrest of two employees of Jordan Goudreau.
